question_text: What are Ruby fibers and how do they differ from threads?
explanation: resume,Fibers are lightweight concurrency primitives for cooperative multitasking. Unlike threads
topic: they must explicitly yield control. Use Fiber.yield and Fiber#resume.

question_text: Explain Ruby's memory model and garbage collection algorithm
explanation: marking, sweeping,Ruby 2.1+ uses generational GC with major/minor collections. Objects start in young generation
topic: promoted after surviving collections. Uses tri-color marking.

question_text: What is Ruby's constant lookup algorithm?
explanation: ancestors
topic: Constants lookup: 1) Lexical scope 2) Inheritance chain 3) Object space. Use :: for absolute lookup. Modules included in ancestors also searched.

question_text: Explain Ruby's method binding and unbinding
explanation: Method#unbind
topic: Method objects can be unbound from original receiver and bound to new objects. Useful for dynamic dispatch: method.unbind.bind(new_receiver).call.

question_text: Explain Ruby's tracepoint API for debugging
explanation: call tracing,TracePoint hooks into Ruby execution: call, return, line, class
topic: etc. Use TracePoint.trace { |tp| ... }. Be careful of performance.

question_text: What is Ruby's Ractor model and thread safety?
explanation: shareable objects
topic: Ractors are Ruby's actor implementation for true parallelism. Each ractor has isolated objects; share only immutable or specially marked objects.

question_text: Explain Ruby's parser and AST manipulation
explanation: abstract syntax tree
topic: Ruby's Ripper module provides access to parser and AST. Use Ripper.sexp(raw_code) to get AST. Useful for code analysis and transformation.

question_text: What are Ruby's enumerators and lazy evaluation?
explanation: external iteration
topic: Enumerators decouple iteration from data. Lazy enumerators enable infinite sequences and chained operations without intermediate arrays.

question_text: Explain Ruby's autoload and zeitwerk constant loading
explanation: load
topic: Autoload defers loading until constant accessed. Zeitwerk (Rails 6+) is modern autoloader with explicit conventions and thread safety.

question_text: What is Ruby's prepend and how differs from include?
explanation: ancestors,Prepend inserts module before class in ancestors chain. Include inserts after. Prepend overrides class methods
topic: include doesn't.

question_text: Explain Ruby's method_added and singleton_method_added hooks
explanation: These hooks fire when methods defined. method_added for instance methods
topic: singleton_method_added for class/singleton methods.

question_text: Explain Ruby's instance_eval vs class_eval
explanation: self modification,instance_eval changes self to receiver, class_eval opens class context. instance_eval defines singleton methods
topic: class_eval defines instance methods.

question_text: What is Ruby's Marshal module and security considerations?
explanation: remote code execution
topic: Marshal serializes Ruby objects. Security risk: loading untrusted data can execute arbitrary code. Use with trusted data only.

question_text: What are Ruby's thread variables and thread-local storage?
explanation: Thread.current[:var] for thread-local
topic: Thread.current.thread_variable_set for fiber-local. Fiber-local variables inherited by child fibers.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Queue and SizedQueue for thread communication
explanation: Queue is thread-safe FIFO. SizedQueue has fixed capacity
topic: blocks when full. Use for producer-consumer patterns.

question_text: What are Ruby's private and protected visibility rules?
explanation: method visibility
topic: Private: can only be called with implicit receiver. Protected: can be called by any instance of same class or descendants.

question_text: What is Ruby's REXML and Nokogiri for XML parsing?
explanation: XPath,REXML is Ruby's built-in XML parser. Nokogiri is faster
topic: C-based alternative with XPath/CSS support. Use Nokogiri for production.

question_text: What are Ruby's Set and SortedSet collections?
explanation: hash-based sets
topic: Set stores unique elements using hash. SortedSet maintains order using red-black tree. Requires 'set' require.

question_text: Explain Ruby's CSV parsing with headers and converters
explanation: encoding,CSV module supports headers, type conversion, and encoding. Use CSV.foreach for streaming
topic: CSV.read for small files.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Date
explanation: Time, DateTime, time zones, precision
topic: Date: calendar date. Time: seconds since epoch with timezone. DateTime: historical dates with time. Use Time for modern timestamps.

question_text: What are Ruby's procs
explanation: lambda, block, return behavior, closure,Lambdas check arity, return from lambda. Procs don't check arity
topic: return from enclosing method. Blocks are Proc objects.

question_text: Explain Ruby's URI and Net::HTTP modules
explanation: REST
topic: URI parses URLs. Net::HTTP makes HTTP requests. Use with OpenTimeout and ReadTimeout. Consider HTTParty for simpler API.

question_text: What is Ruby's YAML and Psych for configuration?
explanation: serialization
topic: YAML is human-readable serialization. Psych is Ruby's YAML parser. Use YAML.load_file for config. Security: use safe_load for untrusted data.

question_text: Explain Ruby's JSON parsing and generation
explanation: Oj gem
topic: JSON module provides parse and generate. Oj gem is faster alternative. Use symbolize_names: true for symbol keys.

question_text: What are Ruby's singleton methods on literals?
explanation: integers, true, false
topic: nil can have singleton methods but they affect all instances. Strings can have real singleton methods.

question_text: Explain Ruby's SecureRandom for cryptography
explanation: tokens,SecureRandom provides cryptographically secure random numbers: random_bytes, hex, base64, uuid. Use for tokens
topic: passwords.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Digest module for hashing
explanation: SHA256, bcrypt,Digest provides cryptographic hashes: MD5, SHA1, SHA256. Use SHA256 for security. For passwords
topic: use bcrypt gem.

question_text: What is Ruby's OpenSSL module for SSL/TLS?
explanation: encryption,OpenSSL provides SSL/TLS, certificates, encryption. Use for secure sockets, HTTPS
topic: certificate verification.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Socket programming basics
explanation: server-client,Socket provides low-level network programming. TCPSocket for TCP
topic: UDPSocket for UDP. Use with IO.select for multiplexing.

question_text: What are Ruby's IRB and Pry for REPL and debugging?
explanation: debugging, console,IRB is Ruby's built-in REPL. Pry is enhanced with syntax highlighting, debugging
topic: source browsing. Use binding.pry for debugger.

question_text: What is Ruby's RubyVM module and MRI internals?
explanation: RubyVM provides access to MRI internals: instruction sequences, abstract syntax tree. MRI-specific
topic: not in JRuby/TruffleRuby.

question_text: What is Ruby's TracePoint for profiling and debugging?
explanation: TracePoint can profile line executions, method calls. Use :line event for line profiling
topic: :call for method profiling.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Ractor messaging and shareable objects
explanation: take, shareable,Ractors communicate via send/yield and take. Only shareable objects (frozen
topic: special classes) can be sent. Copying for others.

question_text: Explain Ruby's pattern matching with case/in
explanation: array/hash matching
topic: Ruby 2.7+ supports pattern matching: case value; in pattern. Deconstructs arrays/hashes. Use for complex conditional logic.

question_text: What is Ruby's numbered parameters and block parameters?
explanation: block parameters,_1
topic: _2 etc are numbered block parameters in Ruby 2.7+. Use for concise blocks: array.map { _1 * 2 }.

question_text: Explain Ruby's non-ASCII identifiers and encoding
explanation: Ruby supports UTF-8 identifiers: methods, variables
topic: classes. Use # encoding: utf-8 comment. Be careful with Unicode normalization.

question_text: Explain Ruby's retry
explanation: redo, next, break
topic: Retry restarts entire iteration. Redo repeats current iteration. Next skips to next iteration. Break exits loop.

question_text: What is Ruby's defined? operator and its return values?
explanation: defined? checks if expression defined. Returns nil if not
topic: or description string. Use for safe method/constant checking.

question_text: Explain Ruby's __FILE__ and __LINE__ constants
explanation: source location
topic: __FILE__ is current file path. __LINE__ is current line number. __dir__ is directory of __FILE__.

question_text: What are Ruby's $SAFE levels and taint checking?
explanation: safe levels
topic: $SAFE levels (0-4) restrict operations. Taint marks untrusted objects. Removed in Ruby 3. Use alternative security measures.

question_text: What is Ruby's Matrix class for linear algebra?
explanation: Matrix class provides matrix operations: multiplication, inversion
topic: determinants. Use for scientific and ML computations.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Prime class for number theory
explanation: Prime class provides prime number operations: checking, generation
topic: factorization. Use for cryptography and algorithms.

question_text: Explain Ruby's fileutils for file operations
explanation: FileUtils provides Unix-like file operations: cp, mv, rm, mkdir
topic: etc. Use for cross-platform file management.

question_text: What are Ruby's pathname for path manipulation?
explanation: Pathname provides object-oriented path manipulation. Use / for path joining
topic: cleanpath for normalization.

question_text: Explain Ruby's memory_profiler for memory analysis
explanation: memory_profiler gem profiles memory allocations. Reports allocations by gem, file
topic: location. Use for memory optimization.

question_text: What is Ruby's concurrent-ruby for concurrency?
explanation: thread pools,concurrent-ruby gem provides high-level concurrency: promises, futures, thread pools, agents
topic: actors. Use for robust concurrency.

question_text: What are Ruby's dry-rb and rom-rb for functional programming?
explanation: composition,dry-rb provides functional tools: validation, transactions
topic: monads. rom-rb is Ruby object mapper. Use for maintainable code.

question_text: Explain Ruby's hanami framework architecture
explanation: Hanami is full-stack Ruby framework emphasizing clean architecture, small memory footprint
topic: and performance.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Sinatra and modular applications
explanation: Rack
topic: Sinatra is DSL for web applications. Supports classic and modular styles. Use Rack middleware. Lightweight alternative to Rails.

question_text: What are Ruby's Rack middleware and builders?
explanation: request processing
topic: Rack is Ruby web server interface. Middleware processes requests in stack. Use Rack::Builder to compose middleware.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Puma and Falcon web servers
explanation: concurrency
topic: Puma is threaded web server. Falcon uses async I/O. Choose based on concurrency model: threads vs fibers.

question_text: What is Ruby's JIT compiler (MJIT) and performance?
explanation: MJIT (Method-based JIT) compiles hot methods to C. Ruby 2.6+ experimental
topic: improved in 3.0+. Use --jit flag.

question_text: Explain Ruby's mruby for embedded systems
explanation: Mruby is lightweight Ruby implementation for embedding. No eval, reduced stdlib. Use for IoT
topic: scripting in applications.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Minitest vs RSpec testing frameworks
explanation: Minitest is built-in
topic: simpler. RSpec has richer DSL for BDD. Choose based on team preference and project needs.

question_text: What are Ruby's bundler and Gemfile.lock?
explanation: dependency resolution
topic: Bundler manages gem dependencies. Gemfile declares dependencies. Gemfile.lock locks specific versions for reproducibility.

question_text: Explain Ruby's rake for task automation
explanation: Rake is Ruby build tool. Define tasks with dependencies. Use for automation: testing, deployment
topic: database tasks.

question_text: What is Ruby's thor for CLI building?
explanation: Thor gem helps build CLI tools with subcommands, options, and documentation. Used by Rails
topic: Bundler.

question_text: What are Ruby's dry-transaction and dry-monads?
explanation: dry-transaction provides transaction pattern. dry-monads provides Maybe, Either
topic: Try monads. Use for functional error handling.

question_text: Explain Ruby's trailblazer for business logic
explanation: Trailblazer provides architecture for business logic: operations, contracts
topic: policies. Keeps models thin.

question_text: What is Ruby's Pact for consumer-driven contracts?
explanation: Pact implements consumer-driven contracts. Consumers define expectations
topic: providers verify. Use for microservices integration.

question_text: Explain Ruby's sidekiq and background jobs
explanation: Sidekiq uses Redis for job queues. Provides retries, scheduling
topic: monitoring. Use for async task processing.

question_text: Explain Ruby's devise and authentication
explanation: Devise provides full-featured authentication: registration, login
topic: password reset. Customizable with modules.

question_text: What is Ruby's graphql-ruby for GraphQL APIs?
explanation: graphql-ruby implements GraphQL server. Provides type system, resolvers
topic: mutations. Use for flexible APIs.

question_text: Explain Ruby's money gem for currency handling
explanation: Money gem provides currency handling: arithmetic, conversion
topic: formatting. Use for financial calculations.

question_text: What are Ruby's i18n and localization?
explanation: I18n provides internationalization: locale files, interpolation
topic: pluralization. Use for multi-language applications.

question_text: Explain Ruby's paper_trail for auditing
explanation: PaperTrail tracks changes to models: who, what
topic: when. Use for audit trails and version history.

question_text: What is Ruby's ruby-prof for profiling?
explanation: ruby-prof is sampling profiler. Provides call graphs
topic: flat profiles. Use for performance optimization.

question_text: What are Ruby's concurrent features in Ruby 3?
explanation: Ruby 3 adds Fiber scheduler for async I/O
topic: Ractors for parallelism. Use for high-performance concurrent applications.

question_text: Explain Ruby's pattern matching in case statements
explanation: Ruby 2.7+ supports pattern matching in case: case value; in [x
topic: y] if x > y. Use for complex conditional logic.

question_text: What are Ruby's numbered block parameters?
explanation: implicit blocks,Ruby 2.7+ supports numbered parameters: array.map { _1 * 2 }. _1 is first parameter, _2 second
topic: etc. Use for concise blocks.

question_text: Explain Ruby's find pattern in pattern matching
explanation: Find pattern in pattern matching: case array; in [*, x, *, y
topic: *]. Matches elements anywhere in sequence.

question_text: Explain Ruby's RubyVM::AST for abstract syntax trees
explanation: RubyVM::AST provides access to Ruby AST. Use parse
topic: parse_file. Useful for static analysis and code transformation.

question_text: What are Ruby's Etc and Sys modules for system info?
explanation: user info
topic: Etc provides user/group info. Sys provides system calls. Use for system-level programming.

question_text: What is Ruby's RubyGems and gem building?
explanation: RubyGems manages gem packaging. Use .gemspec file for metadata. Build with gem build
topic: install with gem install.

question_text: Explain Ruby's pin operator in pattern matching
explanation: Pin operator (^) matches against variable value
topic: not binding. Use in pattern matching to match existing variable.

question_text: What are Ruby's method parameters with ... (forwarding)?
explanation: ... forwards all arguments (positional, keyword
topic: block). Use for delegation and wrapper methods.

question_text: What are Ruby's numbered block local variables?
explanation: _2) act as local variables within block. Can be assigned to
topic: but not recommended.
